item.title: Report I-2024080027
item.description:
Report I-2024080027

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-27T06:25:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-29
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: Southwest Airlines Co
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Crewmember was sitting in a seat charging his cell phone using a battery pack. The crewrnember said that he noticed that the battery pack started swelling then there were sparks and flames. The crewmember threw the pack into the seat next to him. The other crewmembers used the fire extinguisher to put out the flames. There were 12 thru passengers on the flight that were instructed to deplane. Maintenance came on and replaced the seat.

item.title: Report X-2024081670
item.description:
Report X-2024081670

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-26T06:17:30+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-21
  • City: SAN ANTONIO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: DURING RE-WRAP PROCESS, (6) 1 GALLON JUGS OF LOVES WINDSHIELD WASH FLUID, REGULATED AS FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS, TOXIC, N.O.S. (METHANOL), WERE DISCOVERED. NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THIS PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER 8WY786, TRIPPAK SERVICES - INBOUND, 160 ROCHESTER DR STE 126, LOUISVILLE KY 40214-2683. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

item.title: Report X-2024081504
item.description:
Report X-2024081504

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-26T06:17:30+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-16
  • City: FORT WORTH
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The shipment was discovered leaking during sort operations. The package smelled similar to formaldehyde. 1 bottle broken and assumed to be UN2920 Class 8(3). The SDS sheets were inside of the fiberboard box. Inner contents: 6 glass bottles, 6 small plastic bottles (black tape around lid), 3 Plastic Jugs. 9 L total shipped, wrapped in bubblewrap 2 Glass bottles 500ml XTQ017 – UN2920, PGI, 1 broken bottle 2 Glass bottles 500ml each,VBU792 – UN1993 PGII, 2 Glass bottles 500ml each TPL448-UN1993, PGII 2 plastic bottles 500ml each LPQ250 – UN1993 PGIII, 2 plastic bottles NEV805 – UN1993 PGIII, 2 plastic bottles BMW439 - Not Regulated 1 plastic bottle each 1L (CPL830 – UN1993 PGIII), (JTU721 – UN1993 PGIII), (HTY356 - Not Regulated). All contents were placed in a salvage drum and held for FAA investigation.

item.title: Report E-2024080580
item.description:
Report E-2024080580

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-26T06:17:30+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-13
  • City: GRAND PRAIRIE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During the transfer of a 551A1 container filled with liquid, oil-based white paint (overpacked into an 851H2) from the customer's storage facility to a Veolia box truck, an incident occurred. As the drum, weighing over 600 pounds, was being positioned onto a pallet inside the Veolia box truck, a leak was detected. To prevent the drum from slipping and potentially injuring personnel, it was promptly secured on the pallet. However, approximately one gallon of the waste material escaped from the drum, contaminating both the pallet and the box truck's floor. The cause of the leak remains unclear, as the drum's position did not seem to be a contributing factor. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the inner container was missing its bung, which may have played a role in the unexpected release of the waste material.

item.title: Report E-2024080579
item.description:
Report E-2024080579

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-26T06:17:30+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-23
  • City: AMARILLO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Lone Star Hazmat Response was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft-by-2ft area of the concrete dock floor and estimated that twelve (12) ounces of material were released due to the tote being punctured by the cage. Lone Star Hazmat Response personnel transferred the remaining material into a new tote, deployed absorbents, and then swept up the released material. The damaged tote and recovered material were placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum for disposal.

ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel who felt capable of cleaning the release with the PPE available on site.

item.title: Report E-2024080526
item.description:
Report E-2024080526

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-23T15:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-22
  • City: GANADO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: KAG ENERGY, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7940
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The KAG Energy, LLC driver had completed his delivery of diesel fuel into the customer's storage tank. The driver was unfamiliar with the tank's pump system and failed to completely drain the delivery hose. When he disconnected the hose, approximately 10 gallons of diesel fuel was released. Lonestar Environmental responded to the scene and handled the remediation.

One probably had the box laying on its side and the other probably had an heavy box on top of it as well. Because of this, one of the four bottles was crushed on top, causing liquid to come out from the open of a lose cap.
